title: Bernard C. Parks
text:
Bernard C. Parks (born December 7, 1943) is an American <a href="politician">politician</a> and a member of the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a>. He was a member of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20Council">Los Angeles City Council</a>, representing the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20Council%20District%208">8th District</a> in <a href="South%20Los%20Angeles">South Los Angeles</a>.
He also served as chief of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Police%20Department">Los Angeles Police Department</a> from August 1997 to May 2002.
Early life and education.
Parks is a graduate of Daniel Murphy High School and attended <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20College">Los Angeles City College</a> and received a bachelor's degree from <a href="Pepperdine%20University">Pepperdine University</a>. He earned a Master's Degree in <a href="public%20administration">public administration</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Southern%20California">University of Southern California</a>.
Tenure as LAPD Chief & Rampart Division scandal.
During his tenure, the LAPD was rocked by a <a href="Rampart%20Scandal">corruption and police brutality scandal</a> involving the elite <a href="Community%20Resources%20against%20Street%20Hoodlums">C.R.A.S.H.</a> anti-gang unit of the <a href="LAPD%20Rampart%20Division">Rampart Division</a> in the overwhelmingly Latino <a href="Pico-Union%2C%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Pico-Union</a> and <a href="Westlake%2C%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Westlake</a> districts.
The Police Commission, under Commission President <a href="Rick%20J.%20Caruso">Rick J. Caruso</a> did not recommend Parks for reappointment as police chief. Parks was succeeded as chief by <a href="William%20Bratton">William Bratton</a>.
Los Angeles City Council.
Parks won the seat on the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20Council">Los Angeles City Council</a> for <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20Council%20District%208">Council District 8</a> representing <a href="South%20Los%20Angeles">South Los Angeles</a>.
He also unsuccessfully ran for the post of mayor in the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20mayoral%20election%2C%202005">2005 elections</a>, coming fourth in the primary. In 2008, Parks unsuccessfully sought to succeed <a href="Yvonne%20Brathwaite%20Burke">Yvonne Brathwaite Burke</a> on the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20County%20Board%20of%20Supervisors">Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors</a>, losing to <a href="Mark%20Ridley-Thomas">Mark Ridley-Thomas</a> in a <a href="runoff%20election">runoff election</a>.
Term limits forced Parks out of the city council office in 2015. <a href="Marqueece%20Harris-Dawson">Marqueece Harris-Dawson</a> won the District 8 election for the vacant seat, and replaced Parks on 1 July 2015.
